[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: {DESCRIPTION: Think very carefully about the estimated mass, material, stiffness, friction coefficient of the object based off the visual information and semantic knowledge about the object. If object is articulated, do the same reasoning for whatever joint / degree of freedom enables motion. }.
- Environmental Factors: {DESCRIPTION: Think very carefully about the various environmental factors in task like gravity, surface friction, damping, hinge resistance that would interact with the object over the course of the task}.
- The relevant object is {DESCRIPTION: the man's neck, which is assumed to be composed of muscle and bone with skin as an external layer. It is a flexible part of the human body. We can estimate the neck's properties by considering it as a soft, deformable object with an estimated stiffness.} has mass {0.5} kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of {0.6}.
- The surface of interaction is {DESCRIPTION: the robot gripper} has a static friction coefficient of {0.6} with the object.
- Contact Types: {DESCRIPTION: The contact type is a grasping contact with the neck. This requires maintaining a certain force to prevent slippage while applying massage motions.}
- Motion Type: {DESCRIPTION: The motion type involves a combination of pushing and sliding/stroking motions along the neck to simulate a massage. Some small rotations may also occur.}
- Contact Considerations: {DESCRIPTION: To maintain contact, the robot will need to exert forces along the Y-axis (squeezing force) to keep the neck within the gripper, and potentially along the Z-axis to maintain a constant depth of massage. X-axis forces provide the stroking motion. Small torques may be needed to rotate the neck.}
- Motion along axes: {DESCRIPTION: The robot exerts motion in a “linear,” “rotational,” “some combination” fashion along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes}.
- Task duration: {DESCRIPTION: A thorough massage may last for an estimated time duration.}

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: {DESCRIPTION: mass of neck m = 0.5 kg, friction coefficient μ = 0.6, acceleration due to gravity g = 9.81 m/s^2}.
- Relevant equations: {DESCRIPTION: F_friction = μ * F_normal}.
- Relevant assumptions: {DESCRIPTION: Assume the neck is a rigid body and the friction coefficient between the gripper and neck is 0.6.}.
- Computations: {DESCRIPTION: For stroking motion in X, need to overcome friction. Assume a normal force F_normal along Y to hold the neck. F_friction = 0.6 * F_normal. Assume F_normal = 5N, then F_friction = 3N.}
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass {0.5} kg and static friction coefficient of {0.6} along the surface: {DESCRIPTION: The force to overcome friction during the stroking motion (X-axis) is calculated. The normal force is determined by grasp force, which prevents slippage}.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: stroking/sliding motion to massage the neck}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: positive} force along the X-axis with magnitude {3} N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: grasping the neck}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: positive} force along the Y-axis with magnitude {5} N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: maintaining contact with the neck and applying slight pressure during massage}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: positive} force along the Z-axis with magnitude {1} N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: potentially tilting the neck during massage}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular [counterclockwise]} torque about the X-axis with magnitude {0.1} N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: potentially rotating the neck during massage}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular [clockwise]} torque about the Y-axis with magnitude {0.1} N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: slight twisting motion of the neck during massage}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular [clockwise]} torque about the Z-axis with magnitude {0.05} N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force:  {DESCRIPTION: Grasping force must be enough to prevent slippage and maintain a comfortable grip during the massage. Considering the estimated mass, material, and friction coefficient}, thus {4} to {6} N .

```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The neck is composed of muscle, bone, and skin, with an estimated mass of 0.5 kg and a static friction coefficient of 0.6 with the robot gripper."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "The robot will grasp the neck and apply stroking motions along the X-axis, with slight pressure along the Z-axis, while maintaining a grasping force along the Y-axis. Small torques are applied along the X, Y, and Z axes for massage manipulation."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [3, 5, 1, -0.1, 0.1, 0.05]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 5
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 20
```

[end of motion plan]

Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
